basics.name: Paulo Antonacci
basics.label: Ph.D. in Economics & Public Policy (Joint)
basics.summary: Joint Ph.D. candidate in Economics & Public Policy at Duke University. Research focuses on taxation, public economics, and machine‑learning applications for policy.

work.name: The World Bank Group
work.summary: Conducted fiscal diagnostics and policy research across Brazil, Mozambique, Uruguay, Mexico, Belize, and Indonesia, including wage‑bill simulations, PFM assessments, and taxation studies using field experiments and machine learning; contributed to flagship reports and ministerial policy discussions.
highlights: Developed payroll microdata and wage‑bill simulation tools for subnational and federal governments (Pro‑Gestão).
Supported taxation research and RCTs on compliance, including WhatsApp nudges and door‑to‑door enforcement.
Engaged directly with cabinet‑level policymakers and technical teams.

work.name: FGV‑IBRE (Brazilian Institute of Economics)
work.summary: Expanded the Productivity Studies Series using confidential IBGE datasets to analyze firm dynamics and productivity trends in Brazil.
highlights: Worked with restricted‑access microdata at IBGE secure facilities.
Produced empirical analyses of firm dynamics and productivity.

work.name: Harvard Business School
work.summary: Processed restricted firm‑level microdata at IBGE’s secure data center to support productivity research.
highlights: Research collaboration with Professors Laura Alfaro, Naercio Menezes, and Andrea Luchesi.

work.name: Government of Minas Gerais — Delivery Unit
work.summary: Developed social indicators, processed administrative microdata, and authored statistical reports to inform performance targets.
highlights: Built indicator dashboards and documented monitoring reports.

work.name: Caste Away – AIESEC (with NCDHR)
work.summary: Analyzed caste inequality using NFHS‑III and Census microdata with the National Campaign on Dalit Human Rights.
highlights: Produced cross‑state comparative evidence on caste inequality.

honors: M.S. in Computer Science in progress (expected 2026)

publications.name: Who Should the Taxman Visit? Evidence from Door‑to‑Door Tax Enforcement in Indonesia
publications.summary: Door‑to‑door visits increased payment rates by ~7.8 p.p. with persistent effects. Individualized treatment‑effect estimates guide targeting under different policy objectives, revealing equity–efficiency trade‑offs between participation‑ and revenue‑maximizing rules.

publications.name: Low‑Cost Reminders and Property Tax Compliance: Evidence from a Field Experiment
publications.summary: Randomized WhatsApp messages increased current‑year compliance; soft‑tone appeals closed the gap between high‑ and low‑compliance taxpayers and dominated penalty framing over time.

publications.name: The Mechanics of Deforestation Electoral Cycles in Brazil
publications.summary: Tests an administrative mechanism linking political alignment and deforestation via environmental agency staffing; close‑election design suggests alignment increases deforestation.

projects.name: Door‑to‑Door Property‑Tax Compliance (Gorontalo, Indonesia)
projects.summary: Multi‑year empirical project evaluating door‑to‑door tax enforcement, estimating heterogeneous treatment effects and policy‑learning strategies; supports a job‑market paper and related RCT work.
